description: {"blocks":[{"key":"cm1ai","text":"This protocol quantifies light-harvesting complex (LHC) and antioxidant pigments, while simultaneously determining cell density of endosymbiotic dinoflagellates using the Guava Flow Cytometer. Red fluorescence excited by a blue laser represents peridinin, while the red fluorescence excited by the red laser represents both chlorophyll a and chlorophyll c2 . Additionally, green fluorescence off of the blue excitation laser target antioxidant-associated pigments (diadinoxanthin, diatoxanthin, beta-carotene, and flavin-based fluorescent proteins). As flow cytometry continues to gain traction as a robust cell counting methodology, the integration and expansion of this protocol into coral or micro-algal workflows will serve as a valuable tool to quantify the physiology of single photosymbiotic cells in-hospite.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":336,"length":1},{"style":"italic","offset":354,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":805,"length":10},{"style":"sub","offset":355,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"33ji6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"4fbp5","text":"We focus on the characterization of Symbiodiniaceae associated with reef-building corals (Scleractinia); however, we have has success using this for upside-down jellyfish (Cassiopea). Therefore, with slight modifications this protocol may be used for flash-frozen and live cells for both calcifying and gelatinous cnidarians.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":172,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"32qug","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"50hmu","text":"Each {"blocks":[{"key":"fni5m","text":"Prepare tissue slurry (calcifying cnidarians only)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":50}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7crft","text":"Before start:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5umog","text":"Make sure spray gun compressor is turned on","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5r423","text":"Have somewhere to store skeletal fragments after air-brushing (e.g. small weigh boats)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8c322","text":"Be prepared to work efficiently as samples degrade quickly once removed from the freezer","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bu3sj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8o4rf","text":"Locate samples in ultra-low freezer and remove up to 3 samples at a time","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"brk3p","text":"Cut a ~1-2 cm piece from coral fragment (this will vary slightly depending on species)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"63u1c","text":"Use forceps to hold coral fragment just inside the mouth of a 50 mL falcon tube, then use an airbrush loaded with filtered seawater (FSW) to remove all coral tissue from the skeleton making sure to capture the tissue in the falcon tube.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bo236","text":"Depending on the species, this can take 5-20 mL of FSW","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"86pth","text":"Store falcon tube on ice in dim ambient lighting","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8m3sg","text":"Place the remaining skeleton on a weigh boat (Keep track of it. You will need it to normalize cell densities at the end)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"es16b","text":"Repeat steps 5.1-5.3  with all samples","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"937h3","text":"Move quickly and take no more than 1 hour for all samples combined","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6o886","text":"Once all samples have been airbrushed, vortex and needle shear each tissue slurry until homogenized","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"10m5v","text":"Ensure full homogeny of slurry. Allowing any settling or heterogeneity can skew data consistency: There should be no mucus clumps or visible chunks; however, it is normal for small skeletal fragments to settle at the bottom","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
